nodes.text: County-level causal effects on children's adult incomes can be estimated using variation in families who move across counties and these place effects help quantify how much neighborhoods matter, guide moves, and identify area characteristics that improve intergenerational mobility

Method: Estimate county and commuting-zone fixed effects by regressing children's income ranks at age 26 on county exposure years using one-time movers, including origin-by-destination fixed effects and interactions with parental income rank

Data: Deidentified U.S. federal tax records for all children born 1980–1986, locations from yearly ZIP codes, outcomes measured as household income rank at age 26, movers sample limited to single moves before age 23

Identification assumption: conditional on origin-by-destination fixed effects and parent income, the timing (age) of a child's exposure to a place is orthogonal to other determinants of child outcomes (no age-dependent selection into destinations)

Validation evidence: placebo and robustness checks — (i) controlling for pre/post move parental income and marital status does not change estimates, (ii) placebo fixed effects using movers after exposure age and using age-16 labor-force participation are uncorrelated with baseline estimates — supporting key identification

Estimation implementation: hierarchical two-step procedure — estimate origin-destination pairwise effects then recover CZ fixed effects, estimate county-within-CZ effects using within-CZ county movers, normalize to population-weighted mean zero

Result (magnitude): For children from low-income (25th percentile) families, one year in a one-standard-deviation better county increases adult household income by about 0.5% (annual exposure effect ≈ 0.017 percentile? signal annual SD county ≈ 0.165 percentiles), implying roughly 10% higher income from birth (20 years)

Result (variation): There is substantial variation in causal effects across counties and within metro areas; county-level signal standard deviation of annual exposure effects for p=25 is about 0.165 percentiles (larger than CZ-level), so local moves within metros matter

Forecasting method: construct MSE-minimizing forecasts by optimally shrinking mover-based fixed effects toward predictions from permanent residents' outcomes (nonmover averages), using estimated signal and sampling variances to weight forecasts

Result (validation of forecasts / selection): Movers-based causal estimates correlate strongly with permanent-residents outcomes but differ systematically in some places (e.g., New York and Los Angeles have worse causal effects than permanent-resident stats imply), and placebo tests show timing orthogonality largely holds

Correlates and decomposition: Group-level area characteristics (less racial segregation, lower income inequality, better school outputs, higher social capital, lower crime, more two-parent families) are strongly associated with higher causal place effects; most of these correlations are driven by causal place effects rather than sorting

Findings on heterogeneity and policy-relevant implications: (i) boys' outcomes vary more across areas and are especially harmed in high-segregation/high-poverty areas; (ii) areas that generate better outcomes tend to have higher rents on average but rents explain <5% of county-level variance in causal effects, implying many 'opportunity bargains'; (iii) observable components (schools, poverty, family structure) are capitalized into rents but large unobservable components are not — suggesting information frictions and other barriers to mobility; practical implication: place-focused policies and data-informed moves could improve mobility but identification limits and need for finer-grained and subgroup analyses remain
